unnormalised: A new public health initiative is kicking off in Mumbai to tackle the spread of dengue. BMC officials are saying they're going to be focusing on high-risk areas in the city, especially slums and construction sites where water can collect. They're planning to do fogging drives and also educate people on how to prevent mosquito breeding. Remember to empty out any stagnant water in your homes, guys!
normalised: A new public health initiative is kicking off in Mumbai to tackle the spread of dengue. B-M-C officials are saying they are going to be focusing on high-risk areas in the city, especially slums and construction sites where water can collect. They are planning to do fogging drives and also educate people on how to prevent mosquito breeding. Remember to empty out any stagnant water in your homes, guys!

unnormalised: According to the data released by the health dept yesterday, there's been a 20% increase in dengue cases compared to last month. Scary stuff! Dr. Sharma from KEM Hospital says early diagnosis is key. "If you have a fever and body ache, get tested ASAP," she advises. Symptoms like these showing up around monsoon season are likely signs you may have contracted Dengue.
normalised: According to the data released by the health department yesterday, there has been a twenty percent increase in dengue cases compared to last month. Scary stuff! Doctor Sharma from K-E-M Hospital says early diagnosis is key. "If you have a fever and body ache, get tested A-S-A-P," she advises. Symptoms like these showing up around monsoon season are likely signs you may have contracted Dengue.

unnormalised: The campaign will run until 31/12/2024. Let's all do our part to keep Mumbai healthy and dengue-free. Keep your surroundings clean! Rs. 500 fine for anyone found with breeding sites on their property, so beware!
normalised: The campaign will run until thirty first december two thousand and twenty four. Let us all do our part to keep Mumbai healthy and dengue-free. Keep your surroundings clean! Rupee five hundred fine for anyone found with breeding sites on their property, so beware!
